Methods

addScript(src, asyncLoadopt, moduleopt, scriptopt) → {Promise.<void>}

Dynamically loads a script into the document.

Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
src string

The source URL of the script to load.
asyncLoad boolean <optional>
 false

Whether to load the script asynchronously.
module boolean <optional>
 false

Whether the script should be loaded as a JavaScript module.
script HTMLScriptElement <optional>

The script element that will be created (optional).
Returns:
  • A promise that resolves when the script is loaded, or rejects on error.
Type
Promise.<void>

applyDirective(target, name, value, context) → {boolean}

Applies a directive based on its name and value to a target element.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
target HTMLElement

The target element to which the directive is applied.
name string

The name of the directive.
value string

The value associated with the directive.
context Object

The context in which the directive is applied.
Returns:

Returns true if the directive was successfully applied, otherwise false.

Type
boolean

createComponent(constructor) → {function}

Creates a new TurtleComponent instance.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
constructor function

The constructor function for the TurtleComponent.
Returns:

A function that creates an instance of the specified component.

Type
function

debounce(func, delay) → {function}

Creates a debounced function that delays invoking the provided function until after a specified delay period has elapsed since the last time the debounced function was invoked.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
func function

The function to debounce.
delay number

The number of milliseconds to delay.
Returns:

A new debounced function.

Type
function
Example
const handleResize = debounce(() => {
  console.log('Resize event triggered');
}, 200);

window.addEventListener('resize', handleResize);

emitDevEvent(name, data)

Emits a development event for the Turtle framework.

This function creates and dispatches a custom event named "turtledev" if the development mode is activated. The event includes the specified event name and associated data as its detail.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
name string

The name of the event to emit.
data *

The data associated with the event.

ensureNamespace(name, context, path, defer, moduleopt, raiseopt) → {Promise.<void>}

Ensures that a namespace is available in the given context by dynamically loading a script if needed.

Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
name string

The name of the namespace to check.
context Object

The context in which to check for the namespace (usually the global object).
path string

The path to the script that defines the namespace.
defer boolean

Whether to defer loading of the script.
module boolean <optional>
 false

Whether the script should be loaded as a JavaScript module.
raise boolean <optional>
 false

Whether to throw an error if the script fails to load.
Returns:
  • A promise that resolves when the namespace is available.
Type
Promise.<void>

extractName(name, start) → {string|null}

Extracts the name from the directive based on the given prefix.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
name string

The name of the directive.
start string

The prefix to extract from the name.
Returns:

The extracted name without the prefix, or null if the prefix is not found.

Type
string | null

initDevMode()

Initializes the Turtle Development Mode.

This function checks if the development mode is enabled in the Turtle framework. If so, it sets up logging for development tools, initializes tracking for apps and components, and activates additional debugging features.

initListener()

Initializes the event listener for Turtle development events. This function listens for the "turtledev" custom event and processes the details according to the event type.

parseHTML(content) → {Element|null}

Parses a string of HTML content and wraps it in a root element.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
content string

The HTML content to parse.
Throws:

Throws an error if there is a parsing issue with detailed information.

Type
Error
Returns:
  • Returns the root element if parsing is successful, or null if there is a parsing error.
Type
Element | null

process(element, tree, context, data, app)

Processes a DOM tree, creating elements and applying directives as needed.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
element HTMLElement

The parent element to which new elements are appended.
tree Node

The DOM tree to process.
context Object

The context for processing.
data Object

Additional data, including component mappings.
app Object

The application context for components.

processAttribute(target, node, context, data)

Processes attributes of a given node and applies directives accordingly.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
target HTMLElement

The target element to process attributes for.
node Element

The node from which to extract attributes.
context Object

The context in which the attributes are processed.
data Object

Additional data to be used during processing.

render(element, template, contextopt, appopt) → {HTMLElement}

Renders a template by processing its raw HTML and inserting values into it.

Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
element HTMLElement

The parent element to which the rendered content will be appended.
template TemplateStringsArray

The template containing the raw HTML and associated values.
context TurtleRenderData <optional>
 new TurtleRenderData()

The context for rendering, defaulting to a new instance.
app Object | null <optional>
 null

The application context, optional parameter.
Returns:

The parent element after rendering the template.

Type
HTMLElement

throttle(func, limit) → {function}

Creates a throttled function that only invokes the provided function at most once per specified time interval.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
func function

The function to throttle.
limit number

The time interval in milliseconds to limit the function calls.
Returns:

A new throttled function.

Type
function
Example
const handleScroll = throttle(() => {
  console.log('Scroll event triggered');
}, 1000);

window.addEventListener('scroll', handleScroll);
